list.name: Leonard Smith
list.about: Leonard Smith, the father of Jerry Smith and grandfather of Morty Smith, is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty. In the episode 'The Rickshank Rickdemption,' it is revealed that Leonard Smith is an alternate version of Jerry from an alternate reality known as 'Jerryboree.' Jerryboree is a daycare for Jerrys, where they are taken care of while their Ricks and Mortys go on adventures. This revelation adds an extra layer of complexity to Leonard Smith's character, as he is not just a regular character but an alternate version of Jerry. It showcases the mind-bending and multiverse aspects of the show, which is a hallmark of Rick and Morty.

list.name: Lighthouse Keeper
list.about: The Lighthouse Keeper is a minor character from the hit animated series Rick and Morty. In the episode 'Rixty Minutes,' the Lighthouse Keeper briefly appears during one of the interdimensional cable segments. He is shown standing near a lighthouse and saying, 'I'm the Lighthouse Keeper. Your parents put me here to keep me away from drugs and alcohol, but it's not working.' This humorous line is a clever nod to the absurd and random nature of the show. Despite being a minor character with limited screen time, the Lighthouse Keeper's quote has become a memorable and often quoted moment among Rick and Morty fans.

list.name: Lil B
list.about: Lil B is a rapper who makes a guest appearance in the animated series Rick and Morty. In the episode 'Get Schwifty,' Lil B is depicted as a small, floating, and singing head. His character is a satirical take on real-life celebrity guest appearances in popular shows. Lil B's presence adds a humorous and surreal element to the episode, as he collaborates with the main characters to create an improvised song that saves the Earth. This cameo appearance highlights the show's ability to blend various genres and incorporate unexpected elements, making it a fan-favorite moment for both Rick and Morty enthusiasts and Lil B fans.

list.name: Lisa
list.about: Lisa is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Mortynight Run.' Lisa is introduced as an employee at a pawnshop in an alien dimension. She is shown interacting with Rick and Morty, offering them various alien items for sale. However, Lisa's character takes a twist when she reveals herself to be an alien assassin, attempting to kill Rick. This unexpected turn adds a layer of intrigue to Lisa's character, showcasing the show's penchant for surprising plot twists and complex character dynamics. The inclusion of Lisa in the episode adds to the ever-expanding and unpredictable universe of Rick and Morty.

list.name: Little Dipper
list.about: Little Dipper is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Close Rick-counters of the Rick Kind.' Little Dipper is a miniature version of Rick Sanchez from an alternate reality known as the 'Microverse.' In the episode, it is revealed that Rick created the Microverse to power his car battery, enslaving the inhabitants of the Microverse in the process. Little Dipper represents one of the oppressed beings in the Microverse and plays a small yet significant role in the exploration of ethical dilemmas and the consequences of Rick's actions. This character serves as a thought-provoking element in the show, raising questions about power dynamics and morality.

list.name: Lizard Morty
list.about: Lizard Morty is an alternate version of Morty Smith from the animated series Rick and Morty. He is introduced in the episode 'The Rickshank Rickdemption' during a scene where multiple Morty Smiths from different dimensions are shown. Lizard Morty is distinguishable by his reptilian appearance, complete with green scales and a long tail. While Lizard Morty doesn't play a significant role in the series, his inclusion highlights the vast diversity of Morty variants across the multiverse. It exemplifies the show's creativity in designing unique and bizarre versions of its characters, further emphasizing the limitless possibilities within the Rick and Morty universe.

list.name: Loggins
list.about: Loggins is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty. He appears in the episode 'Something Ricked This Way Comes' as a salesman at 'Needful Things,' a mysterious antique shop owned by Mr. Needful. Loggins is shown selling a cursed item called the 'Curse Purge Plus!,' which grants temporary good luck but eventually brings disastrous consequences to the user. Loggins' character is a playful reference to the real-life musician Kenny Loggins, known for his hit songs featured in '80s movies. This clever nod to pop culture adds an extra layer of humor and nostalgia for viewers familiar with Kenny Loggins' music and the films he was associated with.

list.name: Logic
list.about: Logic, the rapper and songwriter, made a cameo appearance in the animated series Rick and Morty. He appears in the episode 'Vindicators 3: The Return of Worldender' as a character named 'Logic Alien.' Logic Alien is a superhero member of the Vindicators, a group of intergalactic heroes. In this episode, Logic Alien teams up with Rick and Morty to solve a series of puzzles and defeat the villain Worldender. Logic's inclusion in the show is a playful homage to his music and popularity among fans. It demonstrates the show's ability to incorporate real-life personalities into its zany and unpredictable universe, providing a delightful surprise for both Rick and Morty and Logic fans.

list.name: Long Sleeved Morty
list.about: Long Sleeved Morty is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty. He appears in the episode 'The Rickshank Rickdemption' during a scene where multiple Morty Smiths from different dimensions are shown. Long Sleeved Morty is distinguishable by his long-sleeved yellow shirt, which sets him apart from the typical short-sleeved Morty attire. While Long Sleeved Morty doesn't have a significant role in the series, his design showcases the show's attention to detail and willingness to experiment with character appearances. This minor variation in Morty's wardrobe adds a touch of uniqueness to the vast array of Morty Smiths in the multiverse, highlighting the show's commitment to visual storytelling.

list.name: Lucy
list.about: Lucy is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Raising Gazorpazorp.' Lucy is a female Gazorpian, an alien species with a matriarchal society. In the episode, Morty accidentally brings home an infant Gazorpian named 'Gazorpazorpfield' and Lucy, as Gazorpian females are solely responsible for reproduction. Lucy serves as a satirical representation of gender dynamics and societal expectations. Her character reflects the show's ability to use science fiction elements to explore social issues in a humorous and thought-provoking manner. Lucy's role in the episode highlights the show's clever and nuanced approach to storytelling and social commentary.

list.name: Ma-Sha
list.about: Ma-Sha is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Raising Gazorpazorp.' Ma-Sha is a female Gazorpian and the mother of Morty's half-Gazorpian son, Gazorpazorpfield. In the episode, Ma-Sha embodies traditional gender roles and stereotypes, often depicted as a frustrated and overworked housewife. Her character serves as a satirical commentary on societal expectations placed on women. The inclusion of Ma-Sha in the episode allows Rick and Morty to explore and subvert gender norms while providing humorous and thought-provoking social commentary. Through Ma-Sha's character, the show challenges traditional portrayals of motherhood and examines the complexities of gender dynamics.

list.name: Magma-Q
list.about: Magma-Q is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Get Schwifty.' Magma-Q is a giant lava monster that appears during the Cromulon's music competition. He is one of the giant heads that demand a hit song to save Earth from annihilation. Magma-Q's design and concept showcase the show's creativity and willingness to incorporate bizarre and larger-than-life characters into its storyline. The inclusion of Magma-Q adds a visually striking and memorable element to the episode, highlighting the show's ability to blend science fiction, humor, and epic spectacle.

list.name: Magnesium-J
list.about: Magnesium-J is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'The Ricks Must Be Crazy.' Magnesium-J is an energy being that resides in the 'Microverse Battery' invented by Rick Sanchez. He serves as a power source for Rick's spaceship. Magnesium-J's character represents the show's exploration of advanced technology and its consequences. By personifying an energy entity, the episode delves into the ethics of harnessing sentient beings for personal gain. Magnesium-J's existence within the Microverse Battery sparks philosophical questions about the value of life and the boundaries of scientific progress, making the episode an intriguing blend of science fiction and moral dilemmas.

list.name: Man Painted Silver Who Makes Robot Noises
list.about: The 'Man Painted Silver Who Makes Robot Noises' is a character who briefly appears in the animated series Rick and Morty. He is shown performing in a street act, mimicking a robot while covered in silver paint. The character is a humorous parody of street performers who imitate robots or statues to entertain passersby. While his appearance is brief, it adds a touch of absurdity and randomness to the show's world-building. The inclusion of such offbeat and peculiar characters showcases the show's knack for incorporating unconventional elements into its narrative, contributing to the distinct and unpredictable nature of Rick and Morty.

list.name: Maximums Rickimus
list.about: Maximums Rickimus is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'The Rickshank Rickdemption.' He is one of the numerous versions of Rick Sanchez from different dimensions. Maximums Rickimus stands out due to his imposing size and muscular physique. While the character doesn't play a significant role in the series, his design adds to the variety of Rick variants showcased in the show. It exemplifies the creative possibilities within the multiverse and the show's ability to incorporate diverse interpretations of its main character, Rick, further enhancing the richness of the Rick and Morty universe.

list.name: Mechanical Morty
list.about: Mechanical Morty is a robotic version of Morty Smith from the animated series Rick and Morty. He appears in the episode 'Rickmancing the Stone,' which parodies the post-apocalyptic genre. Mechanical Morty is a member of a gang of Morty's who have replaced their limbs with mechanical augmentations. His character serves as a nod to the trope of cyborgs or robots in dystopian settings. Mechanical Morty's inclusion adds a dark and edgy element to the episode while further exploring Morty's growth and the complexities of his character. This iteration of Morty exemplifies the show's ability to blend different genres and themes into its storytelling.

list.name: Mechanical Rick
list.about: Mechanical Rick is a robotic version of Rick Sanchez from the animated series Rick and Morty. He appears in the episode 'Rickmancing the Stone,' which parodies the post-apocalyptic genre. Mechanical Rick is a member of a gang of Ricks who have replaced their limbs with mechanical augmentations. His character serves as a satirical take on the trope of cyborgs or robots in dystopian settings. Mechanical Rick's inclusion adds an extra layer of complexity to the episode, showcasing the show's ability to subvert expectations and play with established storytelling conventions. This version of Rick demonstrates the show's penchant for creative world-building and its willingness to explore different iterations of its main characters.

list.name: Medusa
list.about: Medusa is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'The Old Man and the Seat.' Medusa is an alien entity encountered by Rick Sanchez in an intergalactic restroom. She appears as a snake-haired creature capable of turning anyone who looks into her eyes into stone. Medusa's character draws inspiration from Greek mythology, where Medusa is a well-known mythological figure. In the episode, her presence adds a mythical and fantastical element to the show's science fiction narrative. Medusa's inclusion demonstrates the show's ability to blend different genres and folklore references into its unique and eclectic universe.

list.name: Michael
list.about: Michael is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'The ABC's of Beth.' Michael is a sentient gaseous being residing in Froopyland, a whimsical and seemingly idyllic dimension created by Beth's childhood imaginary friend, Tommy. Michael is depicted as a helpful and friendly entity, offering assistance to Beth and Jerry during their visit to Froopyland. However, his character takes a dark turn when it is revealed that he is a serial killer, responsible for murdering Tommy's other imaginary friends. Michael's inclusion adds a macabre twist to the episode, showcasing the show's ability to juxtapose lighthearted and dark elements. This unexpected revelation adds depth to the episode's exploration of childhood trauma and the consequences of unchecked imagination.

list.name: Million Ants
list.about: Million Ants is a character from the animated series Rick and Morty, specifically from the episode 'Vindicators 3: The Return of Worldender.' Million Ants is a superhero member of the Vindicators, a group of intergalactic heroes. His character is a humanoid made up of millions of ants, forming a cohesive entity. Million Ants' inclusion in the episode showcases the show's imaginative and eccentric character designs. His concept adds a visually striking and unique element to the Vindicators team, highlighting the show's ability to create memorable and unconventional superheroes. This distinctive character embodies the show's penchant for pushing the boundaries of creativity within the superhero genre.
